title: Electric induction - changing charge on spheres

content.question: Two solid spheres with the same diameter are on insulating stands, as shown in the figure, and are initially far apart. The spheres are made of different materials and have different initial net charges: Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is made from an insulating material and has a net charge <math alttext="positive Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mpadded></math> distributed uniformly throughout its volume, and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is a conductor with zero net charge. Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is connected to ground with a wire. Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is then moved to be near, but not touching, Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Does the net charge of Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> remain zero when the spheres are brought close to each other? What reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: The net charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> changes. Electrons move from Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> onto Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

The net charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> changes. Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> attracts electrons, which can move from ground onto Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
The net charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> remains zero. There can be no net charge in a conducting material.

The net charge on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> remains zero. The connection to ground prevents any net charge from accumulating on Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> attracts electrons, which can move from ground onto Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
